newsitem.title: COLOMBIA: Colombia offered $3 bln in financing for energy.
newsitem.headline: Colombia offered $3 bln in financing for energy.

text.p: Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi Ltd has offered $3 billion in fresh financing that would be earmarked mostly to support oil and energy projects in Colombia, the Mines and Energy Ministry said.
It said in a statement the offer was made Thursday during talks in Tokyo between senior bank officials and Mines and Energy Minister Rodrigo Villamizar.
Finance Ministry officials could not be reached for immediate comment.

But a spokeswoman at Mines and Energy Ministry said no decision was made yet on whether the offer from Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi would be accepted. There was also no immediate word on terms of the financing deal, she said.

The ministry statement said that if the money was accepted, it would be used, among other things, to help finance the state oil company Ecopetrol's exploration of the sprawling Piedemonte oil and gas field in Colombia's eastern plains.
It would also be used to help finance construction of the Oleoducto Central SA (Ocensa) pipeline, which will connect the giant Cusiana and Cupiagua oil fields with the Caribbean port of Covenas.

Some of the funds would also be used to cover the financing needs of Emcali, the state-run telephone company in Colombia's southwest city of Cali, and to shore up finances at Colombia's foreign trade bank, known by its Spanish-language acronym as Bancoldex, the statement said.
